forkee.name: vscode-gitlens
forkee.description: Supercharge Git inside VS Code and unlock untapped knowledge within each repository — Visualize code authorship at a glance via Git blame annotations and CodeLens, seamlessly navigate and explore Git repositories, gain valuable insights via rich visualizations and powerful comparison commands, and so much more

issue.title: Merge Branch into Current Branch dialog is broken or illogical

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: support-triaged
labels.description: Support has reviewed, verified, or reproduced this

issue.body:
I have a repo, BranchTest, with 2 branches: main and Testbranch.
I have made changes in both branches.

I want to merge the changes from Testbranch into main.
But when I try do do that, I get a dialog that is either faulty or I don't know how to fill out.


- GitLens Version: 11.6.0
- Git Version: 2.33.0.windows.2
<!-- Use Help > Report Issue to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.60.2 7f6ab5485bbc008386c4386d08766667e155244e x64
- OS Version: Windows 10, 21H1, build 19043.1237

Steps to Reproduce:
I open the main branch; I verify that it's selected in the left part of the bottom status bar.
I go to GitLens > Branches > Testbranch.
GitLens shows that "Branch Testbranch is 2 commits behind".
I right click and select Merge Branch into Current Branch.

I get a dialog that says "Confirm merge into branch main"
There's an edit box with the text "Confirm Merge".
There's an option below the box that says
"Cancel Merge. Branch main is up to date with branch Testbranch".
There's also a button with a check mark that says "Will always confirm".

![Dialog](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33486910/135527323-4d9d3b7b-6354-4dc6-ae30-a763b0f04151.png)

comment.body: Same problem for me, using vscode 1.81.3... confirm merge will just not happen even if I push the little checkbox at top right of confirm dialog

issue.title: full issue ref has escape characters that break hover links

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: pending-release
labels.description: Resolved but not yet released to the stable edition

labels.name: needs-verification
labels.description: Request for community verification

milestone.description: Work intended for the November 2023 release

issue.body:
### Description

Some context: I'm preparing a repo to be merged into another repo and I'm rewriting commit messages so that the PR references in the hovers will still link back to the original repo.  I _think_ this is possible by changing the references from `#[pr-number]` to `[owner]/[repo]#[pr-number]` based on [this regex](https://github.com/gitkraken/vscode-gitlens/blob/b1f879373c3d190998a1b378d0ddfc90e9a53d89/src/git/remotes/github.ts#L23).  For example: `try a rewritten squash (#3)` -> `try a rewritten squash (Jacksondr5/test-repo#3)`

However, the hover opens a link with encoded backslashes in the repo name: https://github.com/Jacksondr5/test%5C-repo%5C/pull/3 .  This also happens in the owner/org if there is a hyphen in the name.  I've done a little digging and I think the issue is that the text is being escaped before the link is generated.  I'll try to do some more digging later this week.

Is this a valid use case?  Am I doing this the wrong way?

Reproduction steps (already done in [this repo](https://github.com/Jacksondr5/test-repo)):
1. Start with a repo that has a commit history with PR merges in it
2. Rewrite commits using [git-filter-repo](https://github.com/newren/git-filter-repo): `git filter-repo --replace-message replace.txt` 
    - [git-filter-repo manpage](https://htmlpreview.github.io/?https://github.com/newren/git-filter-repo/blob/docs/html/git-filter-repo.html) 
    - [replace.txt used in example]()
4. Hover over blame in editor to trigger GitLens hover
5. Click PR reference in commit message


### GitLens Version

13.5.0

### VS Code Version

Version: 1.77.1 (user setup)
Commit: b7886d7461186a5eac768481578c1d7ca80e2d21
Date: 2023-04-04T23:21:11.906Z
Electron: 19.1.11
Chromium: 102.0.5005.196
Node.js: 16.14.2
V8: 10.2.154.26-electron.0
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.22621
Sandboxed: No

### Git Version

git version 2.34.1

### Logs, Screenshots, Screen Captures, etc

Before transformation:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9014034/230736427-aed3720a-c951-4544-8dd9-a63586c54b1a.png)
After transformation:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9014034/230736809-e124b874-95cd-4ae3-b103-340c437d3b32.png)

comment.body:
Can you please verify this fix in tomorrow's (`v2023.10.27xx`) pre-release edition of GitLens? Thank you so much!

You can switch to the pre-release edition of GitLens, by clicking on the "Switch to Pre-Release version of this extension" from the Extensions view.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/641685/228608740-6071bc19-7b1a-44c8-843f-d2af44d6114b.png)

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

milestone.description: Work intended for the November 2023 release

issue.body:
### Description

Some context: I'm preparing a repo to be merged into another repo and I'm rewriting commit messages so that the PR references in the hovers will still link back to the original repo.  I _think_ this is possible by changing the references from `#[pr-number]` to `[owner]/[repo]#[pr-number]` based on [this regex](https://github.com/gitkraken/vscode-gitlens/blob/b1f879373c3d190998a1b378d0ddfc90e9a53d89/src/git/remotes/github.ts#L23).  For example: `try a rewritten squash (#3)` -> `try a rewritten squash (Jacksondr5/test-repo#3)`

However, the hover opens a link with encoded backslashes in the repo name: https://github.com/Jacksondr5/test%5C-repo%5C/pull/3 .  This also happens in the owner/org if there is a hyphen in the name.  I've done a little digging and I think the issue is that the text is being escaped before the link is generated.  I'll try to do some more digging later this week.

Is this a valid use case?  Am I doing this the wrong way?

Reproduction steps (already done in [this repo](https://github.com/Jacksondr5/test-repo)):
1. Start with a repo that has a commit history with PR merges in it
2. Rewrite commits using [git-filter-repo](https://github.com/newren/git-filter-repo): `git filter-repo --replace-message replace.txt` 
    - [git-filter-repo manpage](https://htmlpreview.github.io/?https://github.com/newren/git-filter-repo/blob/docs/html/git-filter-repo.html) 
    - [replace.txt used in example]()
4. Hover over blame in editor to trigger GitLens hover
5. Click PR reference in commit message


### GitLens Version

13.5.0

### VS Code Version

Version: 1.77.1 (user setup)
Commit: b7886d7461186a5eac768481578c1d7ca80e2d21

Chromium: 102.0.5005.196

commits.message:
Fixes #2625 adds # escaping to regex
Ensures correct repository on GitHub/GitLab enriched autolinks

issue.title: Log in not working on remote ssh

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: needs-more-info
labels.description: Needs further information, steps, details, etc.

labels.name: area-plus-account
labels.description: Issues or features related to GitLens+ accounts

issue.body:
### Description

I'm working on VS Code by connecting it to a VPC via SSH. The VPC is confined to the company network and doesn't have internet access.

I installed GitLens a couple of days ago and it worked fine (which happened on the VPC via SSH by default). Now I extended the trial, but when I pass the auth URL to vscode it seems to just ignore the log in request. But the `sign in` and `extend pro trial` buttons on the `gitlens: home` tab seem to freeze as well.

### GitLens Version

v13.2.0

### VS Code Version

Version: 1.74.3 (system setup)
Commit: 97dec172d3256f8ca4bfb2143f3f76b503ca0534
Date: 2023-01-09T16:59:02.252Z
Electron: 19.1.8
Chromium: 102.0.5005.167
Node.js: 16.14.2
V8: 10.2.154.15-electron.0
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.19044
Sandboxed: No

### Git Version

git version 2.27.0

### Logs, Screenshots, Screen Captures, etc

issue.title: Allow user to control the --first-parent flag when showing file history

labels.name: feature
labels.description: New feature or request

issue.body:
I have merged two repos using this commands:

```
git remote add project-a /path/to/project-a
git fetch project-a --tags
git merge --allow-unrelated-histories project-a/master # or whichever branch you want to merge
git remote remove project-a
```

Before merging `project-a` into my target repo, I moved all the files in `project-a` to a `packages/project-a` folder, so that they would fit in the structure of the target repo (which is a monorepo).
Now when I look at the file history in gitlens (`gitlens.advanced.fileHistoryFollowsRenames` option set to true), it only shows 1 commit for all files coming from `project-a`, as if they were created from scratch.
When I run this in the terminal:

```
git log --follow <filePath-from-project-a>
```

it shows me the complete commit history.

I looked into the extension code and found that, when displaying the file history, the the `--first-parent` flag is always added to the `git log` command if the `gitlens.advanced.fileHistoryFollowsRenames` option is set to true.
I would like to add a `gitlens.advanced.fileHistoryStopsAtFirstParent` option, so that the user can control the use of the `--first-parent` flag.
I have already prepared a PR for this.

issue.title: Allow user to control the --first-parent flag when showing file history

labels.name: feature
labels.description: New feature or request

issue.body:
I have merged two repos using this commands:

```
git remote add project-a /path/to/project-a
git fetch project-a --tags
git merge --allow-unrelated-histories project-a/master # or whichever branch you want to merge
git remote remove project-a
```

Before merging `project-a` into my target repo, I moved all the files in `project-a` to a `packages/project-a` folder, so that they would fit in the structure of the target repo (which is a monorepo).
Now when I look at the file history in gitlens (`gitlens.advanced.fileHistoryFollowsRenames` option set to true), it only shows 1 commit for all files coming from `project-a`, as if they were created from scratch.
When I run this in the terminal:

```
git log --follow <filePath-from-project-a>
```

it shows me the complete commit history.

I looked into the extension code and found that, when displaying the file history, the the `--first-parent` flag is always added to the `git log` command if the `gitlens.advanced.fileHistoryFollowsRenames` option is set to true.
I would like to add a `gitlens.advanced.fileHistoryStopsAtFirstParent` option, so that the user can control the use of the `--first-parent` flag.
I have already prepared a PR for this.

pull_request.title: Added new input property to enable lazy loading
pull_request.body:
# Description
- Added new input property to enable lazy loading to be in sync with new changes of the GK Graph (see task for more details: https://github.com/gitkraken/GitKrakenComponents/issues/301) 

# Notes
- Works with dependant PR: https://github.com/gitkraken/GitKrakenComponents/pull/300
- For now, I left this PR as draft until changes related with the GK Graph are merged as we need to do a bump of that dependency in `GitLens` side.

# Checklist

- [ ] I have followed the guidelines in the Contributing document
- [ ] My changes follow the coding style of this project
- [ ] My changes build without any errors or warnings
- [ ] My changes have been formatted and linted
- [ ] My changes include any required corresponding changes to the documentation (including CHANGELOG.md and README.md)
- [ ] My changes have been rebased and squashed to the minimal number (typically 1) of relevant commits
- [ ] My changes have a descriptive commit message with a short title, including a `Fixes $XXX -` or `Closes #XXX -` prefix to auto-close the issue that your PR addresses

issue.title: full issue ref has escape characters that break hover links

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: needs-more-info
labels.description: Needs further information, steps, details, etc.

issue.body:
### Description

Some context: I'm preparing a repo to be merged into another repo and I'm rewriting commit messages so that the PR references in the hovers will still link back to the original repo.  I _think_ this is possible by changing the references from `#[pr-number]` to `[owner]/[repo]#[pr-number]` based on [this regex](https://github.com/gitkraken/vscode-gitlens/blob/b1f879373c3d190998a1b378d0ddfc90e9a53d89/src/git/remotes/github.ts#L23).  For example: `try a rewritten squash (#3)` -> `try a rewritten squash (Jacksondr5/test-repo#3)`

However, the hover opens a link with encoded backslashes in the repo name: https://github.com/Jacksondr5/test%5C-repo%5C/pull/3 .  This also happens in the owner/org if there is a hyphen in the name.  I've done a little digging and I think the issue is that the text is being escaped before the link is generated.  I'll try to do some more digging later this week.

Is this a valid use case?  Am I doing this the wrong way?

Reproduction steps (already done in [this repo](https://github.com/Jacksondr5/test-repo)):
1. Start with a repo that has a commit history with PR merges in it
2. Rewrite commits using [git-filter-repo](https://github.com/newren/git-filter-repo): `git filter-repo --replace-message replace.txt` 
    - [git-filter-repo manpage](https://htmlpreview.github.io/?https://github.com/newren/git-filter-repo/blob/docs/html/git-filter-repo.html) 
    - [replace.txt used in example]()
4. Hover over blame in editor to trigger GitLens hover
5. Click PR reference in commit message


### GitLens Version

13.5.0

### VS Code Version

Version: 1.77.1 (user setup)
Commit: b7886d7461186a5eac768481578c1d7ca80e2d21
Date: 2023-04-04T23:21:11.906Z
Electron: 19.1.11
Chromium: 102.0.5005.196
Node.js: 16.14.2
V8: 10.2.154.26-electron.0
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.22621
Sandboxed: No

### Git Version

git version 2.34.1

### Logs, Screenshots, Screen Captures, etc

Before transformation:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9014034/230736427-aed3720a-c951-4544-8dd9-a63586c54b1a.png)
After transformation:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9014034/230736809-e124b874-95cd-4ae3-b103-340c437d3b32.png)

comment.body:
Hello,
We face the same exact situation as @Jacksondr5 after merging a repo into another.
I tried to update to the last GitLens version, and also tried pre-release and the problem is still there.

commits.message:
Fixes view node memory leaks
 - Adds weakEvent function to subscribe to events that will be disposed on GC
 - Reworks children handling and dispose across many view nodes
Splits & moves abstract node classes to new files

Adds support for Cloud Patches

Adds create patch command
Creates a patch and opens the results in an untitled document
Creates patches from command palette, commits, stashes, or comparisons
Adds getDiffFiles to get set of files in the patch
Adds open patch command
Adds cloud patches (wip)
Provides filename (temp) to patch create call
Adds deep link support and open cloud patch command
Adds initial patch details view
Removes PR autolink lookup in patch details
Removes more autolink data
Adds repo choice UX for patch deep links
More patch details cleanup
Fixes patch parsing for renames
Adds commit creation from a patch
Actions UI WIP
Add webviewId to patch details
Adds updated patches section
Adds repo and baseref selection
Fixes date value
Adds wip mode
Updates wip mode
Splits wip details from commit details
Fixes commit details banner and badge
Removes WIP banner and adds tooltip on WIP
Moves git status icons to component
Patch create WIP
Removes patch create WIP
Combines patch create with details WIP
Adds create patch WIP

Co-authored-by: Ramin Tadayon <ramin.tadayon@gitkraken.com>
Co-authored-by: Keith Daulton <keith.daulton@gitkraken.com>
Adds select baseref in share local patch
Adds share from commit details WIP to patch create

Updates patch create flow

Co-authored-by: Eric Amodio <eamodio@users.noreply.github.com>
Adds check UI styles and events
